meanings.definition: To free from illusion or false belief
meanings.sent1: The magician's trick did not disenchant the audience; they still believed in magic.
meanings.sent2: After learning the truth, she felt relieved that the book disenchanting myths was finally revealed.
meanings.sent3: The fairy tried to disenchant the children by showing them how to make their own magic wands.
meanings.sent4: The wise old owl's words had the power to disenchant even the most stubborn of misconceptions.
meanings.sent5: The sunlight streaming through the forest seemed to disenchant the shadows, revealing the beauty hidden within.

meanings.definition: To rid of magic or enchantment
meanings.sent1: The wizard used a special potion to disenchant the cursed amulet.
meanings.sent2: The brave knight's sword had the ability to disenchant any spell cast upon him.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous fairy decided to disenchant the entire garden, turning all the flowers into ordinary plants.
meanings.sent4: The ancient scroll contained a spell that could disenchant any object touched by moonlight.
meanings.sent5: The magician's apprentice accidentally disenchanting the spell book, causing chaos in the enchanted forest.

meanings.sent1: The high expectations of the new movie were quickly disenchanting as the plot unfolded.
meanings.sent2: The hero's failure to save the day disenchant the villagers who had placed their hopes in him.
meanings.sent3: The birthday surprise turned out to be a cake made of cardboard, disenchanting the excited children.
meanings.sent4: The discovery of the truth about Santa Claus can disenchant the innocence of childhood.
meanings.sent5: The grand castle in the distance began to disenchant as they got closer, revealing its worn-down facade.
